docs.lead_paragraph: Many people seem to think they don't have to worry about a preventable disease that does not, at the outset at least, have serious consequences and that can be treated. One such disease was long called adult-onset diabetes. There are two things wrong here: first, this disease does indeed have very serious consequences despite the availability of numerous drug therapies, and second, it is no longer an ailment that occurs almost exclusively in adults.

headline.main: Stampede of Diabetes as U.S. Races to Obesity

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column discusses Type 2 diabetes, which effects more than 16 million Americans; describes how body produces insulin and what breaks down in process and causes Type 2 diabetes; discusses Centers for Disease Control and Prevention analysis, published in Journal of the American Medical Assn and predicting that of those individuals born in 2000, one in three whites, two in five blacks and one in two Hispanics are destined to develop diabetes if current trend continues; experts agree that obesity is primary cause of disease; symptoms of Type 2 diabetes outlined; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Arielle Wilcott, 17, knows the facts of life. Her mother gave her the ''birds and the bees'' talk for the first time when she was 13, and the two women continue an open dialogue on love, sex and relationships. Several years ago, Arielle's junior high school in Sherman, Tex., brought in a health educator to discuss sex, sexually transmitted diseases and birth control. At the end of ninth grade, Arielle and her classmates participated in an assembly that encouraged abstinence.

headline.main: More Teenagers Say No to Sex, and Experts Aren't Sure Why

docs.abstract: David Landry, Alan Guttmacher Institute senior research associate, holds that abortion rate and birthrate decline, noted by Centers for Disease Control and Prevention's annual tally of birth statistics, indicate that teenagers are now more successful in avoiding pregnancy; experts agree that education has been crucial in curbing unwanted pregnancies, but disagree on which message, that of abstinance, birth control or fear of sexually transmitted diseases, including AIDS, has been most persuasive; 17-year-old Arielle Wilcott discusses her view on personal choice of abstinance; teenage birthrate has declined 30 percent over ten years to record low of 43 births per 1,000; photo; graph (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Ever since 1972, when the American public first learned about the Tuskegee syphilis research that subjected African-American men to scientific experiments without their consent, the medical profession has had much explaining to do about its past. Since then, several disturbing instances have come to light. In those cases, scientists, physicians and the government-sanctioned research or treatments that we would today consider unethical, like trials of untested vaccines or medications on mentally retarded children and prisoners.

headline.main: The Ghost of Medical Atrocities: What's Next, After the Unveiling?

docs.abstract: Dr Howard Markel essay explores historic trangressions of medical community, such as Tuskegee syphilis research in which African-American men were subjected to scientific experiments without their consent, and critically regards current efforts by public officials to tender meaningful apologies; Alexandra Minna Stern, University of Michigan historian of medicine, holds that public apologies that just blame predecessors could allow such atrocities to occur again; Markel contends that medical research currently taking place in Africa should be of concern while little is being done to help curb or prevent rampant disease in region (M)
docs.snippet: Ever since 1972, when the American public first learned about the Tuskegee syphilis research that subjected African-American men to scientific experiments without their consent, the medical profession has had much explaining to do about its past.   ...

docs.lead_paragraph: The gap in severity of prostate cancer at time of diagnosis between white and African-American men has narrowed sharply since the advent of guidelines calling for black men to begin screening for the cancer at a younger age, a new study concludes. The study, which tracked over 2,000 cases in Michigan, found that the cancer was being caught at earlier stages in both white and black patients than it was a decade ago, but that the change has been much bigger among blacks.
docs.abstract: Dr Charlie C Pan, University of Michigan researcher, leads study on prostate cancer that shows racial gap in severity of prostate cancer at diagnosis is lessening; American Cancer Society changed guidelines for prostate cancer screening in 1997, suggesting that black men begin screening for illness at age 45; new study supports change; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: The gap in severity of prostate cancer at time of diagnosis between white and African-American men has narrowed sharply since the advent of guidelines calling for black men to begin screening for the cancer at a younger age, a new study concludes.   ...

docs.lead_paragraph: In the dim room at Noble Horizons, a long-term-care center in Salisbury, Conn., glow-in-the-dark stars shone faintly. Colored bubbles rose in a tall lighted column before a mirror. Fiber-optic strands winked orange, yellow and ice white. In recliners, three elderly people sat comfortably, holding teddy bears. Music played softly as scenes of an autumn woods -- a country fence, a deer -- were projected on a wall. This is the Snoezelen (SNOO-zuh-len) room for residents with severe dementia. Donna Hoskins, associate director of nursing, says its effects are intended to stimulate the primary senses with music, soft tactile objects, lighting and fragrances. The stimulation, nurses find, blunts the anxieties of even the most regressive residents and helps them relax.

headline.main: A Room Comes Alive With Color and Sounds

docs.abstract: Snoezelen rooms, first developed in Netherlands in 1970's for use with disabled and elderly, are being re-examined, in part as possible therapy for senior facilities anticipating rise in Alzheimer's cases over next few years; use color, light and sound to achieve patient relaxation, peace and clarity; first-hand observations of Snoezelen rooms given; Dr Barbara Haight, who recently authored review of Snoezelen in Journal of Gerontological Nursing, urges more substantial studies to be completed in order to convince insurance companies to pay for therapy; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A combination of the two most common treatments for an enlarged prostate has significant advantages over using either alone, according to a study published on Wednesday in The New England Journal of Medicine. The study's lead author, Dr. John D. McConnell of the University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center in Dallas, said the combination would be most useful for long-term treatment of men whose prostates were already significantly enlarged.
docs.abstract: Dr John D McConnell, University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center researcher, leads study on treatment for enlarged prostate that finds combination of drugs that works best; findings, published in New England Journal of Medicine, show largest improvements in patients taking both alpha blockers for symptom reduction and finasteride, which works to keep prostate from growing; drawing (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Since the ancient Greeks, physicians have noted that certain personality types appear more vulnerable to infectious diseases. A new study suggests the reason is the hair-trigger response to stress that is more common among extremely shy or withdrawn people. The research, conducted at the University of California, Los Angeles, and published in the December issue of Biological Psychiatry, examined 54 men in the early stages of H.I.V. infection.

headline.main: Shyness and Sickness, Arm in Arm

docs.abstract: University of California (Los Angeles) researchers publish finding of study in Biological Psychiatry that suggests individuals who show social inhibitions or shyness are hit harder by AIDS virus and get fewer benefits from treatment of illness; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: Since the ancient Greeks, physicians have noted that certain personality types appear more vulnerable to infectious diseases. A new study suggests the reason is the hair-trigger response to stress that is more common among extremely shy or withdrawn...

docs.lead_paragraph: Scientists have experimented in recent years with machines meant to use brain waves to tell if someone is lying. Now, British researchers say they have figured out a way to use similar brain waves to tell something slightly different: whether someone is about to make a mistake. The study, presented on Thursday at a conference of the Physiological Society at Cambridge University, reported that changes in a specific, easily monitored kind of brain wave were reliable predictors of a drop in performance on a task requiring prolonged attention.

headline.main: The Brain Wave Made Me Do It

docs.abstract: Dr Avijit Datta of Britain's Medical Research Council, presenting findings of research on human error and brain waves to Physiological Society at Cambridge University, shows how P300 brain waves size coincides with drop in individual's performance and attention (S)
docs.snippet: Scientists have experimented in recent years with machines meant to use brain waves to tell if someone is lying. Now, British researchers say they have figured out a way to use similar brain waves to tell something slightly different: whether someone...

docs.lead_paragraph: In men who have prostate cancer, obesity is linked to an increased risk that the cancer will be aggressive and likely to recur after surgery, two studies have found. A connection to obesity may help explain a racial difference in prostate cancer that has long puzzled researchers: the disease tends to occur at a younger age in black men in the United States than in whites, and is more aggressive and twice as likely to be fatal. In the two studies, blacks had higher rates of obesity than whites, a finding that the researchers said might account for much of the racial disparity in the severity of the disease.

headline.main: Obesity Can Add to Danger In Men With Prostate Cancer

docs.abstract: Two studies published in Journal of Clinical Oncology show link between agressive prostate cancers and reoccurrence of cancer after surgery; Dr Christopher L Amling, Naval Medical Center in San Diego urology department assistant professor who authored both studies, stresses need for men to control weight before onset of cancer; holds that men wanting regimen for health after cancer surgery would do well to reduce Body Mass Index to stave off possible return of cancer; reason for link is not yet known; graph (M)
docs.snippet: In men who have prostate cancer, obesity is linked to an increased risk that the cancer will be aggressive and likely to recur after surgery, two studies have found.    A connection to obesity may help explain a racial difference in prostate cancer...
